title: Kenya: US-Kenya Gov't MOU - Kenya to Use ICTs to Reduce Corruption
text:
Kenya: IEBC Has Neglected Boundary Disputes Role 
The communiqué, the two governments intend to deepen partnerships in four action areas. These include Entrenching Good Governance and Combating Corruption (through deepening partnerships for good governance and institutionalizing integrity and anti-corruption mechanisms in all facets of government), implementing and reinforcing international anti-corruption initiatives and standards, expanding the use of technology to reduce opportunities for corruption while the fourth action area is ensuring accountability for corruption and mismanagement. 
Still under use of technology to reduce opportunities for corruption, the communiqué states that the Kenya government has made a commitment to "deepen ongoing interventions, such as progressively moving all in-bound government payments onto the Government Digital ePayments Platform, and widening the use of the i-Tax and Single Window platforms." 
"At the same time, the Government of Kenya plans to fast track the rollout of digitization of government services under eGovernment to complement the ongoing ePayment program. The Government of Kenya commits to complete the digitization of lands, births, and death records by July 2016, and prioritize business registration records together with other high demanded public records starting August 2016," it adds. 
As part of the partnership, Kenya has also committed "to further enhance its efforts under the Integrated Financial Management Information System program towards full integration of all government financial systems, and to augment the audit and security components to guarantee the system's integrity," with the emphasis being that the government will "consult widely on the development of these various digital programs." 
Kenya is also expected to expand its program to transparently utilize eProcurement systems to eliminate corruption in the awarding of contracts and licenses, and commits to finalizing its transition to eProcurement by June 2016. 
Kenya will also accelerate work to strengthen the capacity of the Financial Reporting Centre (FRC) and Central Bank of Kenya to track illicit financial flow by outfitting the FRC with the requisite platform to run anti-money laundering software. On its part, the US government will provide best practices and advice to Kenya's FRC, and also procure software for the FRC to improve the analysis of suspicious transactions and better communicate with other countries' FRCs once the requisite platform is in place.
